title: Type Face used in Rolling Stone Magazine?
content:
Hello, I’m new here, but can anyone tell me what type faces are currently used in Rolling Stone Magazine? I know Parkinson is used. I’ve read Proxima mentioned in another thread on this site, but I can’t find a solid answer for the body text. Any assistance is greatly appreciated.  
Steve

 [‹ "Des" classic script font w/ loopy cap D](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006023919/http:/typophile.com/node/38968 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for substitutes for House Industries' Holiday Package ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006023919/http:/typophile.com/node/38954 "Go to next forum topic")
author: seraboin

comments.content:
Hi Steven,  
do you have a sample? This question [came up before](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006023919/http:/www.typophile.com/node/38898), maybe you like to [run a search](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006023919/http:/www.google.com/search?q=site:typophile.com%20Rolling%20Stone%20Magazine)?

[The Proteus Project](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006023919/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_overview.php?productLineID=100019) typefaces were originally designed for Rolling Stone. I don’t know if the magazine still uses them.

- Lex

Steven, If you can’t scan a sample for us, you might try using the [Serif Font ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20081006023919/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/SerifGuide/serifsearch.php) to see if you can ID that way. If the typeface is custom, you may at least find something similar.

- Mike Yanega
Looks like nobody here has a copy of Rolling Stone magazine handy, so your best bet would be to scan the type on the pages and post the samples here.
